<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>31</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=33,EFW="2191117",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=991073,FOLIO='31',FILE='DISK128:[09ZAC1.09ZAC15901]DM15901A.;10',USER='GKIBBE',CD=';3-MAR-2009;15:29' -->
<A NAME="page_dm15901_1_32"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Fiscal Year.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We operate on a calendar year ending on the last day in December. For convenience, we refer to the fiscal years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2008, December&nbsp;31, 2007 and December&nbsp;31, 2006 as 2008, 2007 and 2006, respectively. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Our Operating Revenue  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our operating revenue comprises both air travel on a stand-alone basis and bundled with hotels, rental cars and other travel-related
services. We believe our diversified revenue streams distinguish us from other U.S. airlines and other travel companies.  </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Scheduled service revenue.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Scheduled service revenue
consists of air fare for nonstop flights between our small cities and leisure destinations.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Fixed fee contract revenue.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Our fixed fee contract
revenue consists largely of fixed flying agreements with affiliates of Harrah's Entertainment&nbsp;Inc. that provide for a predictable revenue stream. We also provide charter service on a seasonal
and ad hoc basis to several customers.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Ancillary revenue.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Our ancillary revenue is generated from
the sale of hotel rooms, rental cars, advance seat assignments, checked bag charges, in-flight products and other items sold in conjunction with our scheduled air service. We recognize our
ancillary revenues net of amounts paid to wholesale providers, travel agent commissions and credit card processing fees.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Other revenue.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Other revenue is generated from aircraft
and flight equipment leased to third parties. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Seasonality.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our business is seasonal in nature with traffic demand historically being weaker in the third quarter and stronger in the
first quarter.
Our operating revenue is largely driven by perceived product value, advertising and promotional activities and can be adversely impacted during periods with reduced leisure travel spending, such as
the back-to-school season. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Our Operating Expenses  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A brief description of the items included in our operating expense line items follows. Our cost structure is highly variable as we
consider our fixed costs to have represented only 4.60&cent; of our operating expense per available seat mile ("CASM") in 2008, or 45.6% of our 2008 operating expenses. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft fuel expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft fuel expense includes the cost of aircraft fuel, fuel taxes, into plane fees and airport fuel flowage,
storage or
through-put fees. Under certain fixed fee flying agreements, we have been reimbursed by our customers if fuel exceeds a pre-determined cost per gallon, and these reimbursements
are netted against fuel expense. As of January 2009, we are under a new fixed fee flying agreement with Harrah's which provides reimbursement for the entire amount of incurred fuel costs. As a result,
the amount of revenue to be recognized under this agreement and our fuel expense will be reduced as the amount to be paid by Harrah's for fuel cost will be netted against our fuel expense rather than
constituting a part of the revenue we would have otherwise recognized under the fixed fee contract. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Salary and benefits expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Salary and benefits expense includes wages, salaries, and employee bonuses, sales commissions for
in-flight
personnel, as well as expenses associated with employee benefit plans and employer payroll taxes. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Station operations expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Station operations expense includes the fees charged by airports for the use or lease of airport facilities
and fees
charged by third party vendors for ground handling services and commissary expenses. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>32</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=34,EFW="2191117",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=723827,FOLIO='32',FILE='DISK128:[09ZAC1.09ZAC15901]DM15901A.;10',USER='GKIBBE',CD=';3-MAR-2009;15:29' -->
<A NAME="page_dm15901_1_33"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance and repairs expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance and repairs expense includes all parts, materials and spares required to maintain our
aircraft. Also
included are fees for repairs performed by third party vendors. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales and marketing expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales and marketing expense includes all advertising, promotional expenses, travel agent commissions, and
credit card
discount fees associated with the sale of scheduled service. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft lease rentals expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft lease rentals expense consists of the cost of leasing aircraft under operating leases with
third parties.
Also included are maintenance reserves when not considered part of maintenance and repair expense as discussed under "Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates" below. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization expense includes the depreciation of all fixed assets, including
aircraft that
we own, and amortization of aircraft that we operate under capital leases. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense includes the cost of passenger liability insurance, aircraft hull insurance, and all other insurance
policies except for
employee welfare insurance. Additionally, this expense includes travel and training expenses for crews and ground personnel, facility lease expenses, professional fees, personal property taxes and all
other administrative and operational overhead expenses not included in other line items above. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Trends and Uncertainties Affecting Our Business  </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe our financial success is driven by variable factors that affect airlines and their markets, and by trends affecting the
travel industry. The following discussion describes certain key factors we believe may affect our future performance. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Economic Conditions  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The U.S. economy, impacted by the ongoing credit crisis, continues to suffer from extreme negative conditions. These conditions have
created a challenging environment for the airline industry. An uncertainty exists for airline travel demand given tightening of consumer spending. In the near term, the recent reduction in fuel prices
is expected to more than offset the impact of a lower average air fare and uncertain airline travel demand in this current economic environment. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Capacity Management  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In response to rising fuel prices in 2008, we focused on appropriate capacity reductions to ensure continued profitability. Our route
adjustments reflected long-haul route eliminations and frequency reductions, along with new short-haul routes that together drove lower average stage length for the period.
Another focus was to increase passenger loads, which was reflected in greater than 90% load factors during most months in 2008. Together, these measures resulted in significantly lower fuel
consumption per passenger, while higher passenger loads helped drive larger ancillary revenues. Despite the state of the economy, we believe there is sufficient demand to allow us to restore some
capacity from these reductions made in 2008, and to further expand our route network including initiation in second quarter 2009 of scheduled service to our sixth major leisure destination, Los
Angeles. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Demographics and Consumer Behavior  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The airline industry is influenced by lifestyle and demographic trends, and the performance of the broader U.S. economy. We believe the
current demographic and lifestyle trends are positive drivers of </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>33</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=35,EFW="2191117",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=821121,FOLIO='33',FILE='DISK128:[09ZAC1.09ZAC15901]DM15901A.;10',USER='GKIBBE',CD=';3-MAR-2009;15:29' -->
<A NAME="page_dm15901_1_34"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>the
leisure travel industry. The aging of the baby boomers as they enter their peak earning years with more disposable income has had a positive impact on growing consumer demand for leisure travel
generally. We believe the small cities we serve have not been impacted from the current negative conditions in the economy as much as many of the major cities in the country. In addition, we believe
we have a diversified consumer base in our leisure destinations in Florida and Phoenix where we are generating increased travel originating from our leisure destinations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Aircraft Fuel  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The airline industry is heavily dependent on the use of jet fuel and fuel costs represent a significant portion of the total operating
expenses for airlines. Recently, fuel prices have been subject to extreme price fluctuations. In the third quarter of 2008, our average cost per gallon was $3.44 compared to $2.07 for the fourth
quarter of 2008. Fuel availability is also subject to periods of market surplus and shortage and is affected by demand for heating oil, gasoline and other petroleum products. The cost and future
availability of fuel cannot be predicted with any degree of certainty and further fuel cost volatility could significantly affect our future results of operations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Labor  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The airline industry is heavily unionized and the wages and benefits of unionized airline industry employees are determined by
collective bargaining agreements. Conflicts between unionized airlines and their unions can lead to work slowdowns or stoppages. We currently have a non-unionized work force and are not
subject to collective bargaining agreements at the present time. Our pilots and flight attendants have formed in-house associations to negotiate matters of concern with us. Further
attempts are possible to unionize our flight attendants as the waiting period required by the National Mediation Board (NMB) has elapsed since the prior rejection of union representation in December
2006. If our employees were to unionize in the future
and we were unable to reach agreement on the terms of their collective bargaining agreement, or we were to experience wide-spread employee dissatisfaction, we could be subject to work
slowdowns or stoppages. In addition, we may be subject to disruption by organized labor groups protesting our non-union status. Any of these events could have an adverse effect on our
future results. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Competition  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The airline industry is highly competitive. Passenger demand and fare levels have historically been influenced by, among other things,
industry capacity and pricing actions taken by other airlines. The principal competitive factors in the airline industry are fare pricing, customer service, routes served, flight schedules, types of
aircraft, safety record and reputation, code-sharing relationships, and frequent flyer programs. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>34</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_dm15901_1_35"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> 2008 Compared to 2007  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We recorded total operating revenue of $504.0&nbsp;million, income from operations of $55.8&nbsp;million and net income of
$35.4&nbsp;million for 2008. By comparison, in 2007, we recorded total operating revenue of $360.6&nbsp;million, income from operations of $44.1&nbsp;million and net income of
$31.5&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Operating Revenue  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our operating revenue increased 39.8% to $504.0&nbsp;million in 2008 from $360.6&nbsp;million in 2007 due to increases in scheduled
service, fixed fee contract, ancillary and other revenue. The 39.8% increase in operating revenue outpaced a 31.7% increase in total system passengers, indicating our success in increasing revenue per
passenger from 2007 to 2008. The increase in system passengers was in turn driven by a 24.5% increase in system departures and an increase in system load factor from 81.3% to 87.0%. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;System
available seat miles ("ASMs") increased by a more modest 14.9% as the increase in departures was offset by a 7.8% decline in average stage length. System operating revenue per ASM
("RASM") increased by 21.7%, as we successfully grew revenue, particularly ancillary revenue, faster than capacity in 2008. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Scheduled service revenue.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Scheduled service revenue increased 27.8% to $331.0&nbsp;million in 2008 from $258.9&nbsp;million in
2007 driven by a
29.1% increase in the number of scheduled service passengers carried and a 1.0% reduction in scheduled service air fare per passenger. Scheduled service air fare per passenger declined only 1.0%
despite a 4.3% reduction in scheduled average stage length from 2007 to 2008. Scheduled service passenger growth was driven by a 17.8% increase in scheduled service departures and a
6.8&nbsp;percentage point increase in scheduled service load factor to 89.9%. Departure growth in 2008 was driven in part by the full-year effect of our newly established major leisure
destinations of Phoenix and Ft. Lauderdale in late 2007, as well as service increases in our other bases. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fixed fee contract revenue.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fixed fee contract revenue increased 48.5% to $52.5&nbsp;million in 2008 up from $35.4&nbsp;million
in 2007. The
substantial increase in fixed fee contract revenue was primarily due to additional flying under a contract with a third Harrah's Entertainment,&nbsp;Inc. subsidiary that started in
January 2008 and under a contract with MLT Vacations which began in May 2008 and ended in October 2008, neither of which were in place in the prior year. These new contracts more than offset the loss
of revenue from our contract with Apple Vacations West which ended in April 2007. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>35</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=37,EFW="2191117",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=887508,FOLIO='35',FILE='DISK128:[09ZAC1.09ZAC15901]DM15901A.;10',USER='GKIBBE',CD=';3-MAR-2009;15:29' -->
<A NAME="page_dm15901_1_36"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ancillary revenue.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ancillary revenue increased 76.4% to $114.6&nbsp;million in 2008 up from $65.0&nbsp;million in 2007, driven
by a 29.1%
increase in scheduled service passengers and a 36.7% increase in ancillary revenue per scheduled passenger from $21.53 to $29.43. The increase in ancillary revenue per scheduled passenger was due to
the sale of several new products and higher prices charged for certain existing products. For instance, the adoption of checked baggage fees by almost all of the larger airlines in the United States
facilitated the increase in our baggage fees to comparable levels. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other revenue.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We generated other revenue of $5.9&nbsp;million during 2008 as a result of the purchase of six MD-80 aircraft and
three
engines on lease to another airline early in the year. Two of these aircraft were returned to us under the terms of the lease in the fourth quarter of 2008 and one of these was placed in service by
the end of the year. We expect to receive the remaining aircraft and engines under the terms of the lease during 2009. We generated other revenue of $1.3&nbsp;million in 2007 due to the purchase of
eight engines on lease to another airline. We received these engines in the fourth quarter of 2007 under the terms of the lease. While we do not regularly seek to lease aircraft or engines to third
parties, the economics of acquiring these particular aircraft and engines close to the end of their existing leases to third parties were attractive. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Operating Expenses  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our operating expenses increased by 41.6% to $448.2&nbsp;million in 2008 compared to $316.5&nbsp;million in 2007. We primarily
evaluate our expense management by comparing our costs per passenger across different periods which enable us to assess trends in each expense category. The following table presents Operating expense
per passenger for the indicated periods ("per-passenger costs"). The table also presents Operating expense per passenger, excluding fuel, which represents operating expenses, less aircraft
fuel expense, divided by the number of passengers carried. This statistic provides management and investors the ability to measure and monitor our cost performance absent fuel price volatility. Both
the cost and availability of fuel are subject to many economic and political factors beyond our control. </FONT></P>

<TD style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-left:10pt;text-indent:-10pt;"><FONT SIZE=2> </FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Operating expense per passenger</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT"  style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>104.25</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT"  style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>96.96</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>7.5</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>%</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-left:10pt;text-indent:-10pt;"><FONT SIZE=2> </FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Operating expense per passenger, excluding fuel</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT"  style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>50.82</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT"  style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>50.35</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>1.0</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>%</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
per-passenger costs increased at a substantially slower pace than our overall expenses due to a 31.7% increase in the number of system passengers carried in 2008 as
compared with 2007, significantly above the increase in system departures of 24.5%. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table presents unit costs, defined as Operating expense per ASM ("CASM"), for the indicated periods. The table also presents Operating CASM, excluding fuel, which
represents operating expenses, less aircraft fuel expense, divided by available seat miles. As on a per passenger basis, excluding fuel on an ASM basis provides management and investors the ability to
measure and monitor our cost performance absent fuel price volatility. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>36</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=38,EFW="2191117",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=380267,FOLIO='36',FILE='DISK128:[09ZAC1.09ZAC15901]DM15901A.;10',USER='GKIBBE',CD=';3-MAR-2009;15:29' -->
<A NAME="page_dm15901_1_37"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
do not believe CASM is the most appropriate measure by which to evaluate our cost management due to the evolving nature of our route network, our aggressive approach to managing
capacity (i.e.,&nbsp;ASMs) on a seasonal basis, and the low utilization of our fleet which results in many of our expenses being more fixed as opposed to varying significantly with our ASM
production. We provide this table as a convenience because we recognize that CASM is widely used to compare costs in the airline industry. </FONT></P>

<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&cent;</FONT></TD>

<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>%</FONT></TD>

</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft fuel expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft fuel expense increased 50.9% to $229.6&nbsp;million in 2008, up from $152.1&nbsp;million in 2007,
 driven by a
substantial increase in the average cost per gallon to $2.98 during 2008 from $2.30 in 2007, coupled with a 16.6% increase in gallons consumed to 77.0&nbsp;million from 66.0&nbsp;million. The
increase in gallons consumed was in-line with the increase in system departures of 24.5% and the reduction in average stage length of 7.8% for the year. We took significant steps to
conserve fuel during 2008, including taxi-ing with one engine and ensuring flights were flown at more fuel efficient speeds. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Salary and benefits expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Salary and benefits expense increased 29.5% to $72.0&nbsp;million in 2008 up from $55.6&nbsp;million
in 2007, driven
by a 14.2% increase in full-time equivalent employees to support a 30.9% increase in our average fleet from 27.8 during 2007 to 36.4 aircraft during 2008. We employed approximately 1,348
full-time equivalent employees at December&nbsp;31, 2008, compared to 1,180 full-time equivalent employees at December&nbsp;31, 2007. In addition, our monthly average
salary and benefit expense per full-time equivalent increased to $4,206 during 2008 compared to $3,827 during 2007. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Station operations expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Station operations expense increased 28.9% to $43.5&nbsp;million in 2008 compared to
$33.7&nbsp;million in 2007
driven by increased system departures of 24.5%. Station operations expense per departure increased only 3.6% in 2008 compared to 2007 despite much fuller aircraft, as reflected in a
5.7&nbsp;percentage point increase in system load factor from 81.7% in 2007 to 87.0% in 2008. The modest increase in station operations expense per departure occurred despite a significant increase
in the proportion of fixed-fee flying for 2008, which generally has a higher station operations expense per departure. During 2008, 16.0% of total system departures were fixed fee flying,
compared to 11.4% during 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance and repairs expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance and repairs expense increased 60.9% to $41.5&nbsp;million in 2008 compared to
$25.8&nbsp;million in
2007. The percentage increase in expense greatly exceeded the 30.9% increase in the average number of aircraft in our fleet from 27.8 in 2007 to 36.4 in 2008. Among the main reasons for significantly
increased maintenance costs were an increase in repair costs of rotable parts, increased engine maintenance events, and an increase in scheduled heavy maintenance checks from 18 in 2007 to 21 in 2008.
The timing and type of maintenance events may cause our maintenance and repairs expense to vary significantly from period to period and this </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>37</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=39,EFW="2191117",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=361527,FOLIO='37',FILE='DISK128:[09ZAC1.09ZAC15901]DM15901A.;10',USER='GKIBBE',CD=';3-MAR-2009;15:29' -->
<A NAME="page_dm15901_1_38"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>occurred
from 2007 to 2008, as each maintenance event that happened to be required during 2008 was more costly, on average, than those of 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales and marketing expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales and marketing expense increased 12.2% to $14.4&nbsp;million in 2008 compared to
$12.8&nbsp;million in 2007,
driven primarily by an increase in credit card discount fees associated with the 37.5% increase in scheduled service and ancillary revenue. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft lease rentals expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft lease rentals expense decreased slightly to $2.8&nbsp;million in 2008 from
$3.0&nbsp;million in 2007.
The average number of aircraft under operating leases during 2008 was comparable to the average for 2007. In July 2008, we purchased for cash two MD-80 aircraft that had been operated
under operating leases which reduced the total number of aircraft under operating leases to two as of December&nbsp;31, 2008. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization expense was $23.5&nbsp;million in 2008 compared to
$16.0&nbsp;million in
2007, an increase of 46.9%, in-line with the increase in the number of aircraft owned and subject to capital leases which increased from 28 at December&nbsp;31, 2007 to 41 at
December&nbsp;31, 2008. The number of aircraft at December&nbsp;31, 2008 included aircraft on lease to a third party at the time of acquisition. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense increased by 19.6% to $20.9&nbsp;million in 2008 compared to $17.5&nbsp;million in 2007 due mainly
to increased
aviation insurance (as our fleet increased in size), higher loss from engine dispositions, and increased rent associated with our new Company headquarters building. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Other (Income) Expense  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other (income) expense changed from a net other income of $6.6&nbsp;million in 2007 to a net other expense of $0.6&nbsp;million in
2008. This change is primarily attributable to two factors: (1)&nbsp;a gain on fuel derivatives of $2.6&nbsp;million in 2007 compared to a minimal loss on our few remaining fuel derivatives in
2008 and (2)&nbsp;a reduction in interest income earned on cash balances from $9.2&nbsp;million in 2007 to $4.7&nbsp;million as a result of lower prevailing interest rates. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Income Tax Expense  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;While we expect our tax rate to be fairly consistent in the near term, it will tend to vary depending on recurring items such as the
amount of income we earn in each state and the state tax rate applicable to such income. Discrete items particular to a given year may also affect our tax rates. Our effective income tax rate was
35.9% for 2008 compared to 37.9% in 2007. The lower effective tax rate for 2008 was largely attributable to the year-over-year geographic mix of our flying and the impact this
had on the state income tax portion of the tax provision. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> 2007 Compared to 2006  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We recorded total operating revenue of $360.6&nbsp;million, income from operations of $44.1&nbsp;million and net income of
$31.5&nbsp;million for 2007. By comparison, in 2006, we recorded total operating revenue of $243.4&nbsp;million, income from operations of $22.6&nbsp;million and net income of
$8.7&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2007, we had a fleet of 35 aircraft with 32 in service compared with a fleet of 26 aircraft with 24 in service as of December&nbsp;31, 2006. The growth of our
fleet enabled a 34.6% increase in ASMs&nbsp;for 2007 compared to 2006 as departures increased by 43.4% and average stage length decreased by 6.2%. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Scheduled
service ASMs&nbsp;in 2007 represented 88.6% of total ASMs&nbsp;compared to 86.2% in 2006 as scheduled service ASMs&nbsp;increased by 38.4% while fixed fee contract flying
ASMs&nbsp;increased by 11.3%. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>38</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#bg15901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A> </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Operating Revenue  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our operating revenue increased 48.2%, or $117.2&nbsp;million, to $360.6&nbsp;million in 2007 from $243.4&nbsp;million in 2006.
This was driven by a 39.5% increase in total system RPMs&nbsp;and a 10.0% increase in RASM. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Scheduled service revenue.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Scheduled service revenue increased 45.2%, or $80.6&nbsp;million, to $258.9&nbsp;million in 2007 from
$178.3&nbsp;million in 2006 due to a 42.5% increase in scheduled service RPMs.&nbsp;Yield increased 1.9% year-over-year in 2007 due to a 8.3% shorter scheduled stage length
offset by the dilutive effect of introductory pricing on 12 new routes to Las Vegas, eight new routes to Orlando and four new routes to Tampa/St.&nbsp;Petersburg that started during 2007.
Introductory pricing for routes to our two new leisure destinations of Phoenix and Ft. Lauderdale in the fourth quarter 2007 also impacted yield in 2007. The decrease in average stage length coupled
with an increase in load factor of 2.4&nbsp;percentage points resulted in a 4.9% increase in scheduled service RASM from 7.21&cent; to 7.56&cent;. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fixed fee contract revenue.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fixed fee contract revenue increased 4.8%, or $1.7&nbsp;million, to $35.4&nbsp;million in 2007 up
from
$33.7&nbsp;million in 2006. Fixed fee revenues increased principally because of increased flying for Harrah's Entertainment&nbsp;Inc. during 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ancillary revenue.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ancillary revenue increased 107.9% to $65.0&nbsp;million in 2007 up from $31.3&nbsp;million in 2006. The
increase in ancillary
revenue was due to a 55.5% increase in scheduled service passengers and a 33.6% increase in ancillary revenue per passenger from $16.11 to $21.53 due primarily to the introduction of several new
products. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other revenue.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Lease revenue was generated during 2007 of $1.3&nbsp;million related to the purchase of eight engines while on
lease to another
airline. The engines were returned to us in October 2007 with no subsequent lease revenue recognized. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Operating Expenses  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our operating expenses increased by 43.4%, or $95.7&nbsp;million, to $316.5&nbsp;million in 2007 compared to $220.8&nbsp;million
in 2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table presents Operating expense per passenger for the indicated periods. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
general, our operating expenses are significantly affected by changes in our capacity, as measured by ASMs.&nbsp;The following table presents our unit costs, defined as CASM, for
the indicated periods. In addition, the table presents CASM, excluding fuel, which represents operating expenses, less aircraft fuel, divided by available seat miles. This statistic provides
management and investors the ability </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>39</FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>to
measure and monitor our cost performance absent fuel price volatility. Both the cost and availability of fuel are subject to many economic and political factors which are beyond our control. </FONT></P>

<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-left:10pt;text-indent:-10pt;"><FONT SIZE=2> </FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Operating expense per ASM (CASM)</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>8.19</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&cent;</FONT></TD>

<TD style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-left:10pt;text-indent:-10pt;"><FONT SIZE=2> </FONT><FONT SIZE=2>CASM, excluding fuel</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>4.25</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&cent;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>4.15</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&cent;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>2.4</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>%</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft fuel expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft fuel expense increased 49.8%, or $50.6&nbsp;million, to $152.1&nbsp;million in 2007 up from
$101.6&nbsp;million
in 2006. This change was due to a 37.6% increase in gallons consumed due primarily to a 34.6% increase in ASMs&nbsp;and an 8.5% increase in the average cost per gallon to $2.30 per gallon during
2007 compared to $2.12 per gallon in 2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Salary and benefits expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Salary and benefits expense increased 48.4% to $55.6&nbsp;million in 2007 up from
$37.4&nbsp;million in 2006. This
increase is largely attributable to a 39.5% increase in full-time equivalent employees to support our growth. We employed approximately 1,180 full-time equivalent employees as
of December&nbsp;31, 2007, compared to 846 full-time equivalent employees as of December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Station operations expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Station operations expense increased 35.6% to $33.7&nbsp;million in 2007 compared to
$24.9&nbsp;million in 2006. On a
CASM basis, station operations has remained flat since the expense increase during 2007 was in line with our ASM growth. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance and repairs expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance and repairs expense increased by 32.3% to $25.8&nbsp;million in 2007, up from
$19.5&nbsp;million in
2006. The increase in maintenance and repairs expense is largely attributed to the cost from 18 heavy maintenance checks performed during 2007 compared to 14 performed in 2006, along with increase in
routine line maintenance from the growth of our fleet. Maintenance and repairs CASM declined 1.5% as certain maintenance expenses were spread over a larger base of ASMs. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales and marketing expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales and marketing expense increased 37.8%, or $3.5&nbsp;million, to $12.8&nbsp;million in 2007
compared to
$9.3&nbsp;million in 2006. The increase is a result of the advertising and credit card discount fees associated with the 45.2% increase in scheduled service revenue. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft lease rentals expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft lease rentals expense decreased by 41.1% to $3.0&nbsp;million in 2007 from
$5.1&nbsp;million in 2006. On
a CASM basis, aircraft lease rentals expense decreased 55.6% to 0.08&cent; in 2007 down from 0.18&cent; in 2006 due to an increase in the percentage of owned versus leased aircraft. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization expense was $16.0&nbsp;million in 2007 compared to
$10.6&nbsp;million in
2006. The increase of 51.1% was primarily attributable to the number of in-service aircraft owned or subject to capital leases which increased from 22 as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 to 28
as of December&nbsp;31, 2007, as well as the purchase of rotable parts to support the operating fleet. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=42,EFW="2191117",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=757588,FOLIO='40',FILE='DISK128:[09ZAC1.09ZAC15901]DO15901A.;12',USER='ABEAULI',CD=';2-MAR-2009;13:29' -->
<A NAME="page_do15901_1_41"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense increased by 40.4% to $17.5&nbsp;million in 2007 compared to $12.5&nbsp;million in 2006 due mainly
to increased
aviation insurance, facilities and training expenses associated with our growth, along with additional administrative requirements resulting from being a public company. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Other (Income) Expense  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other (income) expense changed from a net other expense amount of $6.7&nbsp;million in 2006 to a net other income amount of
$6.6&nbsp;million in 2007. This change is primarily attributable to two factors: (1)&nbsp;a loss on fuel derivatives of $4.2&nbsp;million in 2006 compared to a gain on fuel derivatives of
$2.6&nbsp;million in 2007 and (2)&nbsp;an increase in interest income from $3.0&nbsp;million in 2006 to $9.2&nbsp;million in 2007 as a result of increased cash balances. We recognized a
$1.6&nbsp;million loss in 2006 on the mark-to-market adjustment for our open fuel derivative contracts and
we recognized $2.6&nbsp;million in net losses for contracts settled in 2006. By contrast, we recognized a $1.7&nbsp;million gain in 2007 on the mark-to-market adjustment
for our open derivative contracts and we recognized $0.9&nbsp;million in net gains for contracts settled in 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Income Tax Expense  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income tax expense for 2007 was $19.2&nbsp;million as our effective income tax rate for the period was 37.9%. Prior to our
reorganization into a corporation at the time of our initial public offering on December&nbsp;13, 2006, we did not pay corporate federal income tax at the entity level and therefore, we did not
incur any federal income tax prior to the initial public offering date. The income tax expense for 2006 was impacted by a $6.4&nbsp;million charge to recognize deferred tax liabilities due to the
tax reorganization carried out in connection with our initial public offering. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our primary sources of funds are cash provided by operations and cash provided by financing activities. Our primary uses of cash are
for working capital and capital expenditures. Historically, we have been able to fund our short-term needs for capital from cash generated from operations. Our long-term needs
for capital are generally for the purchase of additional aircraft. To the extent financing is not available on acceptable terms, we would apply our cash assets to the purchase of aircraft. If we do
not have sufficient cash assets available for this purpose at that time, then we would consider leasing aircraft or deferring their acquisition. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Current Liquidity  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our total cash, including cash and cash equivalents, restricted cash and short-term investments totaled
$190.8&nbsp;million, $186.8&nbsp;million and $144.7&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2008, 2007 and 2006, respectively. Restricted cash represents credit card deposits, escrowed funds under
our fixed fee flying contracts, and cash collateral against letters of credit required by hotel partners for guaranteed room availability, airports and certain other parties. Short-term
investments represent marketable securities which are available for sale. During 2008 and 2007, our restricted cash balances increased by $0.6&nbsp;million and $4.2&nbsp;million, respectively, as
a result of an increase in the number of letters of credit and increases in the amount of a number of existing letters of credit issued to our hotel vendors and some airports. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under
our fixed fee flying contracts, we require our customers to prepay for flights to be provided by us. The prepayments are escrowed until the flight is completed. Prepayments are
recorded as restricted cash and a corresponding amount is recorded as air traffic liability. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>41</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=43,EFW="2191117",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=460657,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK128:[09ZAC1.09ZAC15901]DO15901A.;12',USER='ABEAULI',CD=';2-MAR-2009;13:29' -->
<A NAME="page_do15901_1_42"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Sources and Uses of Cash  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating activities.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2008, our operating activities provided $71.6&nbsp;million of cash compared to $73.9&nbsp;million
during 2007. The
cash flows provided by operations during 2008 were primarily the result of net income plus non-cash depreciation and amortization. We produced a slightly higher amount of cash from
operating activities during 2007 as a result of a large increase in passenger bookings for future travel compared to our air traffic liability balance as of the end of the previous year. Passenger
bookings for future travel as of December&nbsp;31, 2008 decreased due to a tighter future booking curve and general economic conditions. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investing activities.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash used for investing activities in 2008 was $100.5&nbsp;million compared to $68.9&nbsp;million in 2007.
During 2008, our
primary use of cash was for the purchase of property and equipment of $54.1&nbsp;million and $50.0&nbsp;million for the purchase of available for sale securities, net of maturities. The purchase
of property and equipment during 2008 included 15 MD-80 aircraft, two of which were previously under operating leases, five of which were previously under capital leases, six aircraft
purchased free and clear, and two other aircraft purchased with partial financing. During 2007, we used cash of $42.1&nbsp;million for the purchase of property and equipment and $21.3&nbsp;million
for the purchase of available for sale securities, net of maturities. The property and equipment purchases in 2007 included an equipment package made up of eight engines and one airframe, and six
MD-80 aircraft. Two of the aircraft were previously under operating leases, two aircraft were purchased free and clear, and two other aircraft were purchased with partial financing. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financing activities.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2008 we used $18.2&nbsp;million of cash in financing activities compared to
$9.0&nbsp;million provided by financing activities for the same period of 2007. During 2008, we used $16.7&nbsp;million to repurchase common stock and $29.8&nbsp;million to retire capital lease
obligations for five aircraft and make other debt repayments. These uses of cash were partially offset by $25.6&nbsp;million obtained from the financing of ten aircraft. During 2007, the
$22.3&nbsp;million in proceeds from a public stock offering more than offset debt and capital lease financing payments made during that year. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Debt  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Of the 41 aircraft we own as of December&nbsp;31, 2008, we had secured debt financing on 24 aircraft, capital lease financing on two
aircraft, with the remaining 15 aircraft owned free and clear. During 2008, we received proceeds of $25.6&nbsp;million through the issuance of notes payable on ten aircraft, of which eight were
previously owned and debt-free. We also purchased two aircraft through the issuance of notes payable for $7.2&nbsp;million during 2008. The 24 aircraft we have financed with notes as of
December&nbsp;31, 2008 have an aggregate initial borrowed amount of $59.3&nbsp;million and which are scheduled to mature between 2009 and 2012. The equipment notes bear interest at fixed rates
between 6.0% and 8.5% with principal and interest payable monthly. Each note is secured by a first mortgage on the aircraft to which it relates. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_LINERULETXT,NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" -->
<HR NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" >


<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Long-term
debt obligations include scheduled interest payments.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Operating
lease obligations include aircraft operating leases and leases of office space and airport station property. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> OFF-BALANCE SHEET ARRANGEMENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have obligations for aircraft that are classified as operating leases and therefore are not reflected on our balance sheet. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2008, two of the aircraft in our fleet were subject to operating leases. The operating lease terms for these aircraft will expire in 2012. We have the option to purchase these
aircraft in the fourth quarter of 2010. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> CRITICAL ACCOUNTING POLICIES AND ESTIMATES  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations is based upon our consolidated financial statements,
which have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States. The preparation of these financial statements requires us to make estimates and judgments
that affect the reported amount of assets and liabilities, revenues and expenses, and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of our financial statements. Note&nbsp;2 to
our Consolidated Financial Statements provides a detailed discussion of our significant accounting policies. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Critical
accounting policies are defined as those policies that reflect significant judgments about matters that are inherently uncertain. These estimates and judgments affect the
reported amount of assets and liabilities, revenues and expenses, and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of our financial statements. Our actual results may differ
from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions. We believe our critical accounting policies are limited to those described below. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenue Recognition.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Scheduled service revenues consist of passenger revenue which is recognized when the travel-related service
or transportation is
provided or when the itinerary expires unused. Nonrefundable scheduled travel itineraries expire on the date of the intended flight, unless the date is extended by notification from the customer in
advance. Itineraries sold, but not yet used, as well as unexpired credits, are included in air traffic liability. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fixed
fee contract revenues result from charter service provided under long-term agreements and on a seasonal and ad hoc basis. Fixed fee contract revenues are recognized
when the transportation is provided. Under certain of our fixed fee contracts, if fuel exceeded a predetermined cost per gallon, reimbursements are received from the customer and netted against fuel
expense. As of January 2009, we are under a new fixed fee flying agreement with Harrah's, our largest fixed fee customer, which provides reimbursement for the entire amount of incurred fuel costs. As
a result, the amount of revenue to be recognized under this agreement and our fuel expense will be reduced as the amount to </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=45,EFW="2191117",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=1004106,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK128:[09ZAC1.09ZAC15901]DO15901A.;12',USER='ABEAULI',CD=';2-MAR-2009;13:29' -->
<A NAME="page_do15901_1_44"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>be
paid by Harrah's for fuel cost will be netted against our fuel expense rather than constituting a part of the revenue we would have otherwise recognized under the fixed fee contract. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ancillary
revenues are generated from the sale of hotel rooms and rental cars, advance seat assignments, checked bag charges, in-flight products and other items. Revenues
from the sale of hotel rooms and rental cars are recognized at the time the room is occupied or the rental car is utilized. The amount of revenues attributed to each element of a bundled sale
involving hotel rooms and rental cars in addition to airfare is determined in accordance with Emerging Issues Task Force ("EITF") No.&nbsp;00-21: </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenue
Arrangements with Multiple Deliverables</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. The sale of hotel rooms, rental cars and certain other ancillary products are recorded net of amounts paid to wholesale providers,
travel agent commissions and credit card processing fees and are reported in accordance with EITF No.&nbsp;99-19: </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Reporting Revenue Gross As A Principal Versus
Net As An Agent</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. Revenues from change fees imposed on passengers for making changes to nonrefundable itineraries are recognized as they occur. Revenues from our travel
protection product for unlimited changes to nonrefundable itineraries are recognized at the time of purchase. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
revenue is generated from leased out aircraft and flight equipment. Lease revenue is recognized on a straight-line basis over the lease term. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Accounting for Long-Lived Assets.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;When appropriate, we evaluate our long-lived assets in accordance with Statement of
Financial Standards No.&nbsp;144, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. We record impairment losses on
long-lived assets used in operations when events or circumstances indicate that the assets may be impaired and the undiscounted cash flows estimated to be generated by those assets are
less than the net book value of those assets. In making these determinations, we utilize certain assumptions, including, but not limited to: (i)&nbsp;estimated fair market value of the assets; and
(ii)&nbsp;estimated future cash flows expected to be generated by these assets, which are based on additional assumptions such as asset utilization, length of service the asset will be used in our
operations, and estimated salvage values. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft maintenance and repair costs.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance and repair costs for flight equipment are accounted for using the direct
expense method. Under
this method, maintenance and repair costs for owned and leased aircraft, including major overhaul maintenance costs, are charged to operating expenses as incurred. Maintenance deposits paid to
aircraft lessors in advance of the performance of major maintenance activities are recorded as prepaid maintenance deposits, and then recognized as maintenance expense when the underlying maintenance
is performed. These deposits are calculated based on a performance measure, such as flight hours or cycles, and are available for reimbursement to us upon the completion of the maintenance of the
leased aircraft. If there are sufficient funds on deposit to reimburse us for the invoices initially paid by us for these maintenance events, they are reimbursed to us. If at any point we determine it
is not probable we will recover amounts retained by the lessor through future maintenance events, such amounts are expensed. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
maintenance deposits paid under our lease agreements do not transfer either the obligation to maintain the aircraft or the cost risk associated with the maintenance activities to the
aircraft lessor. In addition, we maintain the right to select any third-party maintenance provider. Therefore, we record these amounts as deposits on our balance sheet and then recognize maintenance
expense when the underlying maintenance is performed, in accordance with our maintenance accounting policy. Maintenance deposits totaled $1.1&nbsp;million and $6.4&nbsp;million as of
December&nbsp;31, 2008 and December&nbsp;31, 2007, respectively. Any amounts that are not probable of being used to fund future maintenance expense would be recognized as additional aircraft lease
rentals. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>44</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=46,EFW="2191117",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=676127,FOLIO='44',FILE='DISK128:[09ZAC1.09ZAC15901]DO15901A.;12',USER='ABEAULI',CD=';2-MAR-2009;13:29' -->
<A NAME="page_do15901_1_45"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
determining whether it is probable that maintenance deposits will be used to fund the cost of maintenance events, we conduct the following analysis: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>At
the time of delivery of each aircraft under lease, we evaluate the aircraft's condition, including the airframe, the engines, the auxiliary power unit and
the landing gear.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>2)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Future
usage of the aircraft is projected during the term of the lease based on our business and fleet plan.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>3)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
estimate the cost of performing all required maintenance during the lease term. These estimates are based on the extensive experience of our management
and industry available data, including historical fleet operating statistic reports published by the engine manufacturer, Pratt&nbsp;&amp; Whitney. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
review this asset (the maintenance deposits) for potential impairment in the preparation of our financial statements. Because there have been no material changes to the estimated cost
of expected maintenance events during the remaining term of the leases, no impairment charge was recognized for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, 2007 or 2006. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fuel Derivatives.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We account for fuel derivatives pursuant to the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;133, </FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Accounting For
Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. Since we have not historically qualified for hedge accounting, unrealized changes in the fair value of these derivative contracts
at each period end are required to be included in "Other (income) expense." </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Short-term Investments.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We maintain a liquid portfolio of investments that are available for current operations and to satisfy
on-going obligations. We have classified our short-term investments as "available for sale" and accordingly, unrealized gains or losses are reported as a component of
comprehensive income in stockholders' equity. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Share-based compensation.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have issued common stock, restricted stock and stock options to executives and employees pursuant
to our
long-term incentive plan and warrants to the placement agent involved in our May 2005 issuance of redeemable convertible preferred shares. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;123(R), </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Share Based Payment</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> as of January&nbsp;1, 2006, which requires the recording of stock-based
compensation expense over the requisite service period using a fair value approach similar to the prior pro forma disclosure requirements of SFAS No.&nbsp;123, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for
Stock-Based Compensation</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. Determining the fair value requires judgment, and we use the Black-Scholes valuation model for equity instruments issued. The most significant
judgments required in connection with the use of the Black-Scholes valuation model are the assumptions of volatility of our common stock and the estimated term over which our stock options will be
outstanding. We determine these assumptions from a peer group of publicly traded airline companies due to our lack of historical information regarding our own stock price volatility and option
exercise behavior. Before our stock was publicly traded, we measured fair value based on a variety of metrics including the share price of a peer group for both publicly traded airline companies and
airline stock prices in general, consultation with third parties such as our investment advisors and outside consultants and individual attributes of our Company including our then existing financial
condition as well as future operating prospects. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December 2006, we issued 100,000 restricted shares under our long-term incentive plan which were allocated as of the date of our initial public offering among our
employees at the manager level or below. As required by SFAS No.&nbsp;123(R), the fair value of the shares at the date of issuance was based on our initial offering price, and is being expensed
ratably over the three-year vesting period. The total compensation expense from this restricted share grant will be $18.00 per share for a total expense of $1.8&nbsp;million to be
recognized over a three-year period. We have used our closing share price on the grant date as the fair value for all subsequent issuances of restricted stock. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>45</FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See related disclosure at "Item&nbsp;8&#151;Financial Statements and Supplementary Data&#151;Notes to Consolidated
Financial Statements&#151;Note&nbsp;2&#151;Summary of Significant Accounting Policies." </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Special Note about Forward-Looking Statements  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have made forward-looking statements in this annual report on Form&nbsp;10-K, and in this section entitled
"Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations," that are based on our management's beliefs and assumptions and on information currently available to our
management. Forward-looking statements include the information concerning our possible or assumed future results of operations, business strategies, financing plans, competitive position, industry
environment, potential growth opportunities, the effects of future regulation and the effects of competition. Forward-looking statements include all statements that are not historical facts and can be
identified by the use of forward-looking terminology such as the words "believe," "expect," "anticipate," "intend," "plan," "estimate," "project" or similar expressions. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Forward-looking
statements involve risks, uncertainties and assumptions. Actual results may differ materially from those expressed in the forward-looking statements. Important risk
factors that could cause our results to differ materially from those expressed in the forward-looking statements may be
found in Item&nbsp;1A of this annual report on Form&nbsp;10-K and generally may be found in our periodic reports and registration statements filed with the Securities and Exchange
Commission at </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>www.sec.gov.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> These risk factors include, without limitation, the effect of the economic downturn on leisure travel, increases in fuel
prices, terrorist attacks, risks inherent to airlines, demand for air services to our leisure destinations from the markets served by us, our ability to implement our growth strategy, our fixed
obligations, our dependence on our leisure destination markets, our ability to add, renew or replace gate leases, the competitive environment, problems with our aircraft, dependence on fixed fee
customers, our reliance on our automated systems, economic and other conditions in markets in which we operate, governmental regulation, increases in maintenance costs and insurance premiums and
cyclical and seasonal fluctuations in our operating results. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Any
forward-looking statements are based on information available to us today and we undertake no obligation to update publicly any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of
future events, new information or otherwise.  </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do15901_item_7a._quantitative_and_qual__ite02669"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>  Item&nbsp;7A.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We are subject to certain market risks, including commodity prices (specifically, aircraft fuel). The adverse effects of changes in
these markets could pose a potential loss as discussed below. The sensitivity analysis does not consider the effects that such adverse changes may have on overall economic activity, nor does it
consider additional actions we may take to mitigate our exposure to such changes. Actual results may differ. See the Notes to the consolidated financial statements for a description of our financial
accounting policies and additional information. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Aircraft Fuel  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our results of operations can be significantly impacted by changes in the price and availability of aircraft fuel. Aircraft fuel
expense for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007 represented approximately 51.2% and 48.1% of our operating expenses, respectively. Increases in fuel prices or a shortage of supply could
have a material effect on our operations and operating results. Based on our 2008 fuel consumption, a hypothetical ten percent increase in the average price per gallon of aircraft fuel would have
increased fuel expense by approximately $22.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008. While we do not currently hedge fuel price risk, in the past we entered into </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>46</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=48,EFW="2191117",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=121001,FOLIO='46',FILE='DISK128:[09ZAC1.09ZAC15901]DO15901A.;12',USER='ABEAULI',CD=';2-MAR-2009;13:29' -->
<A NAME="page_do15901_1_47"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>forward
contracts or other financial products to reduce our exposure to fuel price volatility. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, we had no fuel derivative contracts outstanding. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Interest Rates  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have market risk associated with changing interest rates due to the short-term nature of our invested cash, which
totaled $97.2&nbsp;million, and short term investments of $77.6&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2008. We invest available cash in money market funds, certificates of deposit, investment grade
commercial paper, and other highly rated financial instruments. Because of the short-term nature of these investments, the returns earned closely parallel short-term floating
interest rates. A hypothetical 100 basis point change in interest rates for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007, would have affected interest income from cash and investments by
$0.5&nbsp;million and $0.9&nbsp;million, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
long-term debt consists of fixed rate notes payable and capital lease arrangements. A hypothetical 100 basis point change in market interest rates as of
December&nbsp;31, 2008, would not have a material effect on the fair value of our fixed rate debt instruments. Also, a hypothetical 100 basis point change in market rates would not materially impact
our earnings or cash flow associated with our fixed-rate debt.  </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do15901_item_8._financial_statements_and_supplementary_data"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>  Item&nbsp;8.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financial Statements and Supplementary Data    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following consolidated financial statements as of December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007 and for each of the three years in the period
ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 are included below. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="DO15901_TOC"></A> </FONT></P>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_START_LINKTABLE -->

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
